tissue_cell_morphology:
Diffuse infiltrate of monotonous medium-sized cells within the dermis and subcutis, with sparing of the epidermis and skin adnexal structures. The neoplastic cells contained a scanty rim of amphophilic agranular cytoplasm, and irregular nuclei
with finely dispersed chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli.

Diffuse proliferation of small to medium-sized hematolymphoid cells involving the dermis and extending to the deep subcutaneous adipose tissue. The cells showed coarse chromatin and irregular nuclear contours with readily identifiable mitotic figures. There was no apparent tumor necrosis. The epidermis was spared of involvement. Interspersed lymphoid aggregates, composed predominantly of small lymphocytes with scattered larger activated forms, were noted to be scattered throughout the tumor.

Dermis and subcutis contained a dense monotonous infiltrate of medium-sized to large tumour cells with immunoblast-like morphological features. Mitotic activity was brisk. Necrosis or angioinvasion was absent.

Dense and relatively monomorphous lymphoid infiltrate spanning
the superficial and mid-dermis. In foci, the cytology was reminiscent of centrocytes, with
elongated, twisted or folded nuclei, indistinct nucleoli, and scant cytoplasm.

Periadnexal, perivascular, and interstitial neoplastic cells infiltrated in the dermis, sparing the epidermis. The tumor cells were characterized by enlarged and mildly irregular nuclei, fine chromatin, prominent nucleoli, and scant cytoplasm. Here were some mitoses. Angioinvasion and coagulated necrosis were absent.

Diffuse and dense infiltrate of medium-sized lymphoblastoid cells exhibiting irregularly shaped nuclei in the dermis and subcutis. There was a nar- row grenz zone separating the tumor cells from the epidermis; however, epidermotropism of tumor cells was not seen. Histochemical analysis of the biopsy showed absence of neutrophils, eosinophils, and plasma cells. In addition, there was no evidence of angiocentric lymphoma, necrosis, or hemaphogacytosis.
Biopsies of the skin lesions and bone marrow revealed cells with a blastic appearance.

Dermal lymphomatous infiltrate with an alveolar growth pattern, which extended into the subcutis. The epidermis was not involved, and a grenz zone was present between the epidermis and the infiltrate. The monomorphous infiltrating cells were medium-sized cells with finely dispersed chromatin and absent or indistinct nucleoli. The cytoplasm was scant and appeared grey-blue and agranular upon Giemsa staining. Neither angiocentrism nor angiodestruction was evident.

A skin biopsy showed a diffuse infiltration of the dermis by a neoplastic
population of medium-to-large-sized blastic cells. The epidermis was not involved, and a grenz
zone was visible between the epidermis and the dermal
infiltrate. There was prominent hemorrhage, but
neither necrotic areas nor angiotropism was observed.

The anatomical-pathological study of the lesions showed a skin fragment with dense dermo-hypodermic nodular infiltrate, composed of medium-sized cells and immature appearance, with irregular nuclei, inconspicuous nucleoli, scant cytoplasm and no azurophilic granules. Epidermotropism, necrosis, or angioinvasion were not observed.

Histologically, both lesions were characterized by
sheets of homogeneous, medium-sized neoplastic cells with
a nonepidermotropic distribution, infiltrating mainly the
dermal and subdermal layers of the skin.

Pathological examination of the LN biopsy revealed a lymphomatous infiltration composed of small to medium-sized elements without cytoplasmic azurophilic granules, effacing nodal architecture by diffuse proliferation.

Histopathological examination revealed that the tumor extended from the dermis to the cutaneous adipose tissue, and no invasion of the epidermis was detected. The tumor cells were plasmacytoid, ranged in size from small to intermediate, and had a high nuclear-cytoplasmic (N/C) ratio. Because they were AE1/AE3-negative, an epidermal tumor was ruled out. Nucleoli were present, the nuclei were not irregular, and there was little apoptosis.

Diffuse and nodular infilltrate, medium-sized cellswith scant eosinophilicor clear cytoplasm. The common histopathological features were dense, nonepidermotropic diffuse and/or nodular infiltrates composed mainly of medium-sized cells with a high mitotic rate and erythrocyte extravasation.

The anatomical-pathological study of the lesions showed a skin fragment with dense dermo-hypodermic nodular infiltrate, composed of medium-sized cells and immature appearance, with irregular nuclei, inconspicuous nucleoli, scant cytoplasm and no azurophilic granules. Epidermotropism, necrosis, or angioinvasion were not observed.

a nonepidermotropic distribution, infiltrating mainly the
dermal and subdermal layers of the skin.

Nucleoli were present, the nuclei were not irregular, and there was little apoptosis.
